questions.question_text:
A Sales Manager wants all Sales Users in the department to see a Dashboard that displays Total Closed/Won Opportunity Amount by User on a monthly basis.
The Opportunity sharing model is private.
How can the Administrator meet this requirement?

choices.B: Create the Dashboard from the Opportunities by User Report, select the Sales Manager as RunAs User and save in the private Dashboard Folder.
choices.C: Ask the Sales Manager to create the Dashboard from the Opportunities by User Report and save it to her private Dashboard Folder.
choices.D: Ask the Sales Manager to create the Dashboard from the Opportunities by User Report, select ג€View Dashboard as Meג€ and save in the shared Dashboard Folder.
choices.A: Create the Dashboard from the Opportunities by User Report, then save in the shared Dashboard Folder as a Dynamic Dashboard.
Sales Rep B needs to be assigned to the Sales Rep role.
choices.D: Sales Rep B needs to be assigned to the Sales Rep profile.
choices.C: Sales Rep B needs to be assigned to the Sales Rep permission set.
choices.B: Sales Rep B needs to be assigned to the Sales Rep queue.

questions.question_text:
Sales Rep and Sales Rep B view an Account report for all Accounts without any filters. The company uses a private sharing model. Each rep sees a different number of results.
What is the explanation for the discrepancy in the reports?

discussion.content:
https://help.salesforce.com/articleView?id=000333143&type=1&mode=1

Explanation - answer A is correct.
A, is the correct answer

comments.content: Profile does not provide you with record access. Roles do. OWD is the most restrictive record access setting. Roles and Hierarchies makes holes to that restriction. So correct answer has to be A

discussion.content: Private OWD means that "only the record owner and the users above that role in the hierarchy can view edit and report on those records." Since they're both sales reps, role have nothing to do with it the answer should be profile (Answer D).

Moderator's answer A is correct:
Ref:
Record level security is affected by below 4 items.
1. OWD setting
2. Roles & roles heirarchies
3. Sharing rules
4. Mannual sharing
Plz, confirm the correct answer.
A is correct since Each user, group, or role can have its own level of access to a report .
Correct answer is D
A or D ?? plz confirm after proper verification with proof
A is right, Record level security bases on role
Answer is D

questions.question_text:
Ursa Major Solar's default, organization-wide sharing for accounts is set to Public Read/Write. The Administrator needs to ensure that Marketing never modifies an Account record.
Which action should the Administrator take to accomplish this goal?

choices.B: Separate the Marketing role hierarchy from the Sales role hierarchy.
choices.D: Switch Organization-Wide Default Sharing to Public Read Only.
choices.C: Remove Edit access on Accounts from the custom Marketing profile.
choices.A: Assign a permission set to Marketing users which removes Edit permission.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
It is C, though I also thought it was D at first.

OWD gives access to records. Without Edit permission on the Account object in profile, even if you have Public R/W via OWD on Account records, you will never be able to modify it.
It is D, as even if you remove the Edit access user will still be able to edit it as OWD is set to Read/Write

I think it's D: 
Read only is a more restrictive setting tha Read/Write. 
Can someone confirm?

comments.content: I think it should be C. Setting OWD to Public Read would remove Edit access to everyone that is currently allowed to do so.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Only A is true. B cannot be true

Selected Answer: AB
A. Sharing is inherited from parent
B. Child needs to be manually deleted when parent is deleted

Master/Detail relationships in custom objects have the following characteristics:

A. Sharing is inherited from the parent: The child records inherit the sharing and security settings of the parent record.

B. Child needs to be manually deleted when parent is deleted: If the parent record is deleted, the child records are also deleted automatically.

Option C is incorrect. Both parent and child fields are available for reporting in a Master/Detail relationship.

Option D is incorrect. In a Master/Detail relationship, the child record is automatically deleted when the parent record is deleted, so it is not required.

comments.content: B is incorrect: Have you even tried it first? When you delete a parent object in A Master-Detail relationship, the child records are automatically deleted. Come on!
what is the source of this info?
Nope, B is wrong, read carefully again.
B is not correct. In case of Master detail the child field automatically get deleted when parent is deleted. We don't delete it manually

discussion.content: B is also Correct, If the Parent is deleted child get also deleted in the master details relationship
D is incorrect, Lookup field to parent is required on child

comments.content: Perhaps the answer meant to be "Lookup field in child is required".

questions.question_text: Which of the following are true about Master/Detail relationship in custom objects?

choices.B: Child needs to be manually deleted when parent is deleted
choices.C: Only child fields are available for reporting
